Situation1: They provide in-depth guidance on a critical task where mistakes could have serious consequences.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, toggling between two open windows on my screen. As a mentor, I was supposed to guide my new trainee, Jamie, through the intricacies of our company’s latest service. The task was critical—one misstep in the process could cost a client thousands. Jamie’s questions came rapid-fire, each one more detailed than the last, and I felt the weight of responsibility to share everything I knew, to ensure he understood every nuance.

But the phone lines were lighting up. As a telemarketer, I was expected to handle customer objections smoothly, stick to the script, and keep calls moving. Today, though, prospects were unusually curious, pressing for technical details the script barely touched. My supervisor’s messages blinked insistently: “Keep calls under three minutes.” I could hear Jamie’s uncertainty in his voice, and I could hear the impatience in the customers’ tone. My mind raced, torn between giving Jamie the thorough guidance he needed and fielding calls with the efficiency my job demanded. My heart pounded as I realized I couldn’t possibly do both well at the same time.
